p: Most CMIP5 models (24/32) predict reduced ITCZ strength (i.e., weaker upward motion) under global warming (Fig. 3c), with a median fractional weakening of 0.69%/K and an interquartile range of 1.75%/K. As is the case for changes in ITCZ width, this weakening is more robust across climate models than changes in ITCZ location, though there is considerable inter-model spread. Although the ITCZ weakens with warming on average, this weakening is the small residual between two larger quantities: strongly reduced ascent on the equatorward edges of the ITCZ and increased ascent in the core of the ITCZ [ 29, 30, 33] (Fig. 4a). This pattern of vertical velocity changes in the ITCZ has been termed the “deep-tropics squeeze” [ 29] and, in addition to thermodynamically driven changes in atmospheric moisture, it strongly shapes the hydroclimate response to climate change [ 76, 92]. A weakening of the ITCZ is consistent with the general weakening of the overturning atmospheric circulation with warming [ 28, 93– 97]. In the next section we discuss the relationship between changes in ITCZ width and strength.
